data.title: Stowaways, storms and suspense on the first airship flight to US
data.meta_description: Ninety years ago this week a huge Clyde-built airship lifted off from East Fortune airfield in East Lothian and set off on what has become one of the great, but almost forgotten achievements of
data.text:
Ninety years ago this week a huge Clyde-built airship lifted off from East Fortune airfield in East Lothian and set off on what has become one of the great, but almost forgotten achievements of British aviation. The flight of the R34 was the first crossing of the Atlantic by an airship - and if John Alcock and Arthur Brown had not made their non-stop flight by Vickers Vimy just three weeks earlier, would have been the first airborne crossing from Britain to America, .

In fact, the R34 should have been the first aircraft across the Atlantic. The flight was originally planned for April, 1919, but the refusal of the Germans to sign the Treaty of Versailles meant it was kept on standby in case
